3F81CA6F7C114999941A0FFBC3D876A6.description: Identify characteristics of traditional music styles (e.g., traditional powwow music, Métis fiddling).

C2555A35AB7840C4B14E24622F85E2A2.description: Identify characteristics of individual dance styles (e.g., grass dance vs. traditional or fancy dance, Métis jigging).

19CE6E9381F14E5FB8AE1CC49D1B466B.description: Investigate the distinct characteristics of First Nations and Métis dances and dance regalia including connections to history (e.g., historic banning of traditional dance and other cultural practices).

11C0C6BFD5B04BCB86E3DDD85681AD33.description: Compare differences among traditional arts expressions (e.g., Métis sash weaving, porcupine quillwork, and beadwork designs).

5465410F90BC4A1A909737A5A69208BA.description: Describe key features of traditional arts expressions of Saskatchewan First Nations and Métis artists.

A28646C26631432F904623AB143581A0.description: Describe and analyze key features of arts and cultural traditions found in own community (e.g., heritage dances, country music bands, children’s theatre productions).

ABF574CAAD354351A9AC85B7E0BC9AD4.description: Investigate the arts and cultural traditions found in own community.

A00C8A5B19074BA2A8397118E623B540.description: Describe how people in own community participate in the arts in a variety of ways.

7C7A9EC5DCFC4589B0A294EB6399112D.description: View and listen to the work of artists from various cultural groups.

D00A82822A6A4DE496227A09A92FFBD4.description: Recognize there are a variety of arts expressions in Saskatchewan (e.g., film, dance, theatre, music, photography, graphic design, sculpture, architecture).

C9DDB8BEFEE24E09B17A25EBD4B0ACC2.description: Respond to a variety of arts expressions (e.g., contemporary, historical, cultural, and popular) in own communities (i.e., local, geographic, cultural).

1DE8E71EFF944CFCA6C0B3EAD1B3B1A5.description: Describe how, from earliest times, human beings have influenced their communities through the creation of arts expressions (e.g., architecture, music, theatre, storytelling, and dance).

C0806574D72B46CCBB0CC36A22703CEB.description: Identify key features of arts and cultural traditions in own community.

B0BFF301804C4AB5ACD79E733E23E379.description: Cultural/Historical (CH) - Children will investigate the content and aesthetics of the arts within cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts and understand the connection between the arts and human experience.

9888AB4CA5DC4A2A909013399F8994BA.description: Document and share collaborative inquiry findings with other students or with a community audience.

1528C4D42E724C0995B9CC7370A6F05A.description: Manage information discovered about the arts using different methods including technology (e.g., audio recorders, portfolios of pictures, word processors).

B50AF5159490483281134B9C645C2FDE.description: Locate information about the arts from various sources (e.g., interviews, books, local resource people, the Internet).

5D05B11285B84C1E825A3D6CE93866BD.description: Plan how to answer some or all of the questions posed as a whole group or in small groups

1872CA8CABBC41A8A8BDFAB2BDEA25C0.description: Pose questions about the arts and determine which questions are compelling enough to investigate as a group (e.g., Who are the artists who live, or have lived, in our community? What does, or did, their work say about our community?).

5FCD7314CBA544A689B091DC20260060.description: Investigate various arts expressions in own communities, throughout the world, and in different eras (e.g., pyramids, cathedrals, public sculptures) using technology.

FC90AB8117354DA99543AFE66EC464B3.description: Use libraries, community resources, and the Internet as sources of information about artists and their work.

C02FC9FD0B7A4A4B997187BDFBA4EE34.description: Use inquiry and technology to investigate a variety of arts expressions.

30C83BCC8321472A975E8FE2A4A7ACC1.description: Respond to arts expressions in own communities, both verbally and non-verbally.

A9A6357233BD4C65AB3B4C64EC434143.description: Investigate and discuss why arts expressions are created in various communities (e.g., purpose for traditional Ukrainian dances).

472A1FC34D9042DAB8C2C54247B11791.description: Investigate and describe how artists and their work affect our visual environment and other forms of daily interactions (e.g., graphic design, radio, media, clothing).

CE7FD00A8556441DB30782B7DCC05058.description: Demonstrate sensitivity to differing responses and interpretations, recognizing that not everyone responds the same way to a work of art

9F60B850BEC04454B2F9491485F0C372.description: Recognize that an audience will not see or hear everything in an arts expression at first introduction.

92CE0DCE44B14FBE96166FD178195D78.description: Discuss, with guidance, how the arts tell something about the society or community in which they were created.

865A09ACDA08489C951A37E138BAEC0F.description: Describe or infer how art works are created for a variety of reasons.

178EB3636AD64D2E81AE33AEF6E637CA.description: Examine arts expressions to determine how ideas for arts expressions may come from artists’ own communities.

D5B559A983E64229B10843BC63748DD0.description: Critical/Responsive (CR) - Children will respond to artistic expressions of Saskatchewan, Canadian, and International artists using critical thinking, research, creativity, and collaborative inquiry

6CF75B0895844DBEB44066473D740226.description: Describe and represent the position of objects relative to other objects (e.g., space and size).

2230A4FD37AE4B52ADF218E72FD55106.description: Identify examples of contrast in own surroundings and in art works.

AF86A0C7EC0C4532B2EBC149B1543855.description: Classify different kinds of patterns using own words (e.g., striped, dotted, mixed up) and apply to own work.

7F345A9C0FB34FB59FADC66FDD6E786F.description: Identify basic forms such as cubes and spheres, and recognize that forms have space all around them.

0E82CD3F67F24B028994D81084797788.description: Classify different kinds of shapes using own words (e.g., rounded, lumpy, square) and apply to own work.

7081384721C7408E8F2BBFE292A8C1A5.description: Classify different kinds of textures using own words (e.g., rough, smooth, soft) and apply observations to own work.

9E4439F0D0284B7B81F05AB656B0894B.description: Investigate and illustrate how the same colour can be light or dark.

E16108149D0141D396B049433A998AB3.description: Illustrate how secondary colours are created when combining two primary colours.

36BD4FA0A17B45AA87801A9AD1D57097.description: Classify a large variety of lines using own words (e.g., wavy, jagged) and apply in own work.

3730FBEE9E66454BA35CDC5CEAD180F1.description: Demonstrate safety, co-ordination, and skills in using simple visual art tools and materials.

C7CB3B1E1B56480DA4E8EBC99D6E40D4.description: Make basic decisions about own methods (e.g., scratching into the surface) and materials (e.g., fabrics, found objects).

513D7E9DB9ED416C935C442198F48E1E.description: Create art works using a variety of visual art concepts (e.g., secondary colours), forms (e.g., collage, drawing, painting, sculpture, mobile, traditional art), and media (e.g., paper, found objects, paint, crayons).

904C8EE8491749E4B7A6FAEA4B957283.description: Recognize, with guidance, how own visual images communicate non-verbally.

B5FB5E7431884C0CA528E74DE1171090.description: Identify sources of inspiration and describe decisions made in creating own art works

EFF18B0A9883436498A83706C1DBE3B2.description: Reflect and discuss to help make decisions about own art works.

7A97E81854614B8C832207FAF98FE0FF.description: Describe how ideas for visual expressions come from many different sources.

059A2CD92BEB4F95972285AE65FCAEEC.description: Compare differing ideas in art works, including own and peers’ visual expressions.

D304E188BF9843D79D267D3D331AFAF9.description: Investigate and observe how people, animals, and objects look different from different points of view

F4A4120492904FE19D09D199343F73DF.description: Identify the difference between two dimensions and three dimensions.

E3EF03877B6045209EB8FC3040C01E97.description: Explore size relationships by measuring using non-standard referents or comparisons

85096ADFAD904F61B328180A0026D8D6.description: Identify and represent details in the appearance of plants, animals, people, and objects (e.g., lines, textures, shapes, shadows)

511B8D5C43324D40BDDAD68E32A5F8C4.description: Use inquiry processes to explore a question or topic related to interest in own community

F6C9EFC9372548A7A5F5A0B1F588E050.description: Use own words, and music terminology, to develop common understanding and use of the language (e.g., introduce terminology such as rhythm, dynamics, pitch as required in gradeappropriate repertoire).

A10B33CF35364DC2B75B126AE1923089.description: Compare and use varieties of tone colour/timbre in speech and music

DF33AF6D37814C42997E10D4D1CDCC27.description: Investigate various ways of creating harmony (combining pitch and rhythm) and texture, and recognize differences in sounds heard alone and sounds heard together

69B953049CA54D0490F2DF4CC357CBC4.description: Compare and use different pitches (high/low sounds) and pitch direction (moving up/down, staying the same) in speech and music

B165C4EC246441658383B756143CD800.description: Compare and use different tempos (fast/slow, faster/slower paces) and dynamics (loud/soft, louder/softer sounds) in speech and music.

990A2B7D25824D4A9EDD213B93E16694.description: Perform and create various grade-appropriate melodic and rhythmic osintati (patterns) using repetition and contrast

7C3502F919E3491C9C373192534EA803.description: Maintain a steady beat (pulse) and identify accents with a strong movement.

02F33F51D00843229EF723BD529F2859.description: Incorporate different sounds from a single sound source in music compositions

05039CACDB274C5F88568F82F8DB1D79.description: Explore contrasts between sounds with voice and instruments.

E304268D8B7F4D358D4DF3027D0C9250.description: Contribute to music inquiry questions and processes to explore form and the elements of music (e.g., How could each group represent AB (i.e., binary) form using voices, bodies, or instruments in different ways?).

88AC9188C4734816ADFE34CFE3E5EC4F.description: Create and perform music that demonstrates understanding of: • form (repetition and contrast) • beat (strong and weak beats/accents) and meter (2/4 and 4/4) • rhythm (create ostinati) • tempo (fast/slow paces) • dynamics (loud/soft) • pitch (high/low sounds) and pitch direction (moving up/ down/staying the same) • texture (layers of sounds) • tone colour (variety).

1750E0BFBB7543CFB3BAAF828429DC81.description: Experiment with invented and traditional notation as a way of preserving compositions, recognizing that sounds/music may be represented through a variety of notation devices.

5A363CA183124150BC7D69662750F54A.description: Describe decisions made in selection and use of sounds, instruments, and order

0A797BC006AE49D4B675A61E75317458.description: Use reflection and discussion to learn and make decisions about own music expressions.

8D752AA2FB1F4151BAB577EFCF477956.description: Discuss images and expressive qualities evoked by music expressions

3103D8311658480FA493A8D9464F2EDA.description: Select and create sounds for composition with purpose, recognizing that different combinations of instruments, voices, or sound objects create different effects.

A4869C8898234F8197C7ED95B91F8CDE.description: Make decisions (individually and collaboratively) about ideas, sounds, instruments, and order in creating a music expression.

B3437D4102DC4EB8AE71D684852AE373.description: Describe sources of ideas for music compositions (e.g., sounds of machines, parks, playgrounds, or neighbourhoods).

B8FFDEA11B1744F1B55FF7AD3E683563.description: Sing and create songs and chants using ideas sourced from the students’ communities (e.g., songs about farms, cities, or the environment) and from various cultural communities, controlling breathing, pitch, rhythm, and dynamics

B82F0EBA78584407A6DF3F972E368C3A.description: Make distinctions between different voices and voice qualities in speech and song.

56817F380F09499E84EE6B0B0A7B530E.description: Describe the elemental characteristics of sounds from a variety of settings in the community.

F0507B155D3C488F8B93459C98A3D6E4.description: Experiment with a variety of simple found objects and selected instruments, both pitched and unpitched (e.g., two notes on a xylophone vs. sounds that have no discernible pitch, such as a tambourine or slapping a thigh)

02EA9E0D056E485F95B3D4617C12A113.description: Create sound compositions using communities as inspiration

EBC0EB5153E94FCEB963FB23F0F21E6D.description: Demonstrate use of imagination when exploring various possibilities in dramatic contexts.

38BCDCCB593F48AB9357371D11753F10.description: Use strategies other than discussion to reflect on drama work (e.g., use tableaux to recall the time order of the sequence of events, or use drawings or flashbacks to further explore previous experience).

1D614B9E5C7142079B981CAD76BB8401.description: Discuss how strategies such as role, flashback, or tableau worked in the drama and begin to use the correct terminology

D8598C0A062C4D0C9B1519559EED7094.description: Contribute to drama discussions with stories of own experience (e.g., talk about connections among thoughts, feelings, and actions)

3E02757C710F4DDF84ADEBE53B99A0F5.description: Recall and respond to the drama work, both in and out of role

02405B14555547AAAB1FB8F754DF155D.description: Recognize, with guidance, how characters/roles, objects, and places can represent ideas

3A4967727D7F4868A4289D38B062DDF0.description: Use visual images and language to represent ideas, both in and out of role

782D74A449D04B2A8770895CF3FF650B.description: Describe the main ideas of each dramatic episode.

927C003781144F0EB5531D45E9424766.description: Use libraries, resource people, the Internet, and other sources of information for drama work.

0A1A936FFF0549FE81FF3832D8FFA0CE.description: Use inquiry processes to explore a question or topic that is of individual or group interest for contextual drama (e.g., questions and research about how animals change in winter might inspire a drama about an animal community preparing for a harsh winter).

A98DF709E94D4FD19ECCFEE9218E72B7.description: Contribute ideas when engaged in a variety of drama strategies (e.g., role, parallel play, journeys, meetings) and during periods of reflection.

3D91B8213C3A45DA985D4B113173B6F9.description: Use observations of own community as inspiration when working in and out of role (e.g., local rodeo event or farmers’ conversation on coffee row).

4DE0062BC3F94F7A93407B8B059F4620.description: Discuss how some roles may display more power and authority than others at different times during the drama (e.g., Max’s mother displays power over him when she sends him to bed, and Max displays his own power when he becomes King on the Wild Things’ island community in a drama inspired by ‘Where the Wild Things Are’).

4FF01F74E4EB4AD9A0BC2971556C0281.description: Accept surprises in the drama and be willing to incorporate new information into unfolding episodes of the contextual drama

A75B5F2F42814CCC839AFAFA7EF358F5.description: Use imagination to explore various possibilities in dramatic contexts.

1CB22B046352473EB1E6BBFEC61770FB.description: Listen to and respect the contributions of others

88C23242BF91410EBAA9CFED67DDD38B.description: Collaborate with others and recognize the need to work together within dramatic contexts.

12651D88F7154821951C084E862AD4F5.description: Adopt roles in dramatic situations and interact appropriately with others in roles drawing on imagination and own understanding of the context (e.g., community).

C7E7A5EEC0824E7B90BDD882A4241B29.description: Demonstrate a willingness to enter into the fiction provided by the drama.

E348F5EB2D244660A43622F1F0DE2184.description: Using own words, classify and investigate movement relationships with a partner or an object (e.g., beside, behind, above, below).

A40FDAEFC47742CDA0E068ED54828BE3.description: Explore and identify a variety of directions, levels, sizes, and shapes in personal and general space

EB685EEBA13F44F5826D912F2B1E45DB.description: Use straight or curved pathways or combinations of both in movement explorations.

9C0900AAA9E84861B7F69B8F0325932B.description: Classify even and uneven rhythmic patterns of various movements.

4AFA10EFBFFA49DCB2A4675A739F7E62.description: Move with a variety of speeds (fast and slow), duration (short and long), and varying forces (push and pull, strong and light) for expressive purposes

0B3873B517D44CC3ABDBF16C8D36F1D9.description: Identify and investigate different kinds of locomotor (travelling) and non-locomotor actions, and explore a variety of ways to walk, run, leap, slide, gallop, jump, hop, turn, twist, bend, stretch, and pause.

07CEE85BF2F64D5C8EAF3270DDB19CCF.description: Identify how various parts of the body can act as a base to support the rest of the body (e.g., supporting the body with one foot and one hand).

9ADB66260E1B467E812F4744F5658F17.description: Demonstrate and discuss how movement patterns can repeat and contrast

C41BB205D1EC484FBB76F5923C840A4F.description: Explore and solve movement problems, or inquiry questions, in several different ways (e.g., How many different ways can we use the scarves or streamers in straight pathways and curved pathways?).

E97D38A1F39D4D269384E1F00BB96BE2.description: Observe the motion of objects and people and incorporate these observations in movement explorations.

62B78174E6A242BFABA7B6B187F07C5D.description: Seek a variety of solutions in movement explorations (improvisation).

755432EFA0B3467893DE77AB98A0DBD7.description: Create and connect dance phrases using the elements of dance including: actions (identify variety), body (bases), dynamics (move with varying speeds, duration, forces), relationships (using own words, classify variety of relationships with partner or object such as above, below, beside) and space (straight or curved pathways or combinations).

90EC00E16C0942F99A431DB9E86EF9CA.description: Reflect and discuss ideas with peers to help make decisions about own dances.

B8DC0C909E3C442C8CDFD530FDA24709.description: Identify and compare characteristics of own and peers’ dances.

656E65806A08458FB8BAF354AF1ECE53.description: Ask questions related to the stimuli to contribute to dancemaking inquiry process (e.g., How can we show this idea in our movement?).

B00BFF224D72414EBC77F7CEF1EA8AAA.description: Recognize how various stimuli such as personal observations, stories, poems, music, or objects can be used as starting points for own dance explorations.

4D1B76B7DF39496FA9BA230DC58EED15.description: Describe and use dance ideas drawn from sources in own community (e.g., occupations, vehicles, or nature in and around our community).

2EBB6CF90AF544DCB7C73AADF53CE288.description: Extend own body’s range of movement and strength

AFB4B36A9F414F6D98C3EC94BDD16E49.description: Create dance phrases that have a beginning position and an end position.

B0AFCA4C98B54EBAA8AFE1E89589BF4E.description: Select and connect movements from explorations to create dance phrases

B8056783837144C492617B48B8E3497B.description: Create and connect dance phrases using ideas about community as stimuli (e.g., our school, community events, farm life, city life, cultural heritage).

5D2576B179094A5AB1F68DB8621AACFA.description: Creative/Productive (CP) - Children will inquire, create, and communicate through dance, drama, music, and visual art.
